column1: #Text=Polycrystalline samples of Ca2CeCr2TiO9 and SrLaCrSnO6 were synthesised using the traditional ceramic method.
#Text=To form SrLaCrSnO6, stoichiometric quantities of SrCO3, Cr2O3, SnO2 and pre-dried La2O3 were ground in an agate pestle and mortar for 30 min and then fired at 900 °C as a loose powder for 16 h.
#Text=The resulting mixture was reground, pelletised and fired at 1300 °C for 6 h.

#Text=The sample was subsequently fired at 1350 °C for 48 h and then at 1400 °C for 48 h at a time until the reaction was deemed, on the basis of the X-ray powder diffraction pattern, to have gone to completion.
#Text=After each firing the sample was quench-cooled to room temperature and re-ground and re-pelleted.
#Text=Stoichiometric quantities of CaCO3, Cr2O3, TiO2 and pre-dried CeO2 were used as starting materials to form Ca2CeCr2TiO9.
#Text=The same firing sequence was used to form Ca2CeCr2TiO9 as was used to form SrLaCrSnO6 except that an additional final firing at 1450 °C for 48 h was required.
#Text=The polycrystalline sample of SrLaCrSnO6 produced was brown in colour whereas Ca2CeCr2TiO9 was a fine black powder.
